description:
We have two phenomenal speakers lined up for this meetup to help you explore how you can build applications that leverage Watson’s cognitive capabilities in the Cloud.

First: Meet Watson

Meet Carmine Dimascio (Developer for Watson), as he walks you through all of the different Watson Services currently available on Bluemix. Carmine will also show you how to build a Watson app using Bluemix, and share how he used Watson to build a brewery app. Check out his blog to learn more about Carmine and his work.

Second: See Watson in action

Janet Powers, the CEO of Women’s Toolbox— a company dedicated to empowering and educating women about technology and business—will show the app she created using Watson Services and Bluemix. The Client Profiling app helps business owners improve client acquisition, retention, and engagement by modeling past “perfect” clients with prospects in the pipeline.
name: What will you do with Watson?

description:
Tesla, BMW i8, they are very modern & fashion to cars, not only a new car, also a revolution for automotive industry.

But, there is a big gap to such electronic cars, "power provider".

Let's image, if those electronic cars can't get power as easy as fuel now for traditional cars, the revolution couldn't go further.

It will must be happened in the near future. We can be sure that millions of "power provider" lied on the roads, which "power provider" will provide easy, fast service to cars. There are many business opportunities to us. How to manage such a lot of "power provider"? What kind of value-added service we can find out?

We could meet-up and find the appropriate services which can host in cloud service.

e.g. Create a manage system for "power provider", and can listen every "power provider" node status, to schedule a maintenance plan.

It's brand new business for every company, and it's a "blue sea".

Let's discover the chance and take advantage.
name: Cloud Service to smart electronic cars industry
group_name: Chengdu PaaS and Bluemix Computing Meetup

name: Lets meetup and discuss whatever we know about the platform

description:
Title: A leap forward for SQL on Hadoop

Abstract:

We will discuss the various SQL on Hadoop alternatives and explore why suchtechnologies have become an area of keen interest for many organizations.We will discuss various alternatives such as Hive and Impala and theirpros/cons. We will share customer use cases for Warehouse Modernizationand the role of SQL for Hadoop in this space, as well as discussperformance characteristics of SQL on Hadoop when running common queryworkloads. We will provide an intro to Big SQL and demo. Big SQL deliverssome exciting capabilities including comprehensive SQL functionality thatleverages advanced SQL compiler/runtime all with low latency and highperformance.

Learn more about Big SQL here:http://www.livestream.com/newchannel/popoutplayer?channel=ibmiod&clip=pla_e4b28ad8-f647-4a02-88ad-6679b78f7e8b&time=1481. Check out the SQL on Hadoop white paper:http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/cgi-bin/ssialias?subtype=WH&infotype=SA&appname=SWGE_SW_SW_USEN&htmlfid=SWW14019USEN&attachment=SWW14019USEN.PDF

Speaker:

Claus Samuelsen, IBM

Claus Samuelsen has many years experience within data management, and has for more than 3 years had big data as his primary focus area.Working with customers all over Europe devolping Hadoop based solutions in several industries from banking, insurance, healthcare to automotive and gaming.

--------------

Title: Apache Cassandra & Apache Spark for Time Series Data (45 minutes)

Presenter: Patrick McFadin

Bio: Patrick McFadin is regarded as one of the experts of Apache Cassandra and data modeling techniques. As the Chief Evangelist for Apache Cassandra and consultant for DataStax, he has helped build some of the largest deployments in the world. Previous to DataStax, he was Chief Architect at Hobsons, an education services company. There, he spoke often on Web Application design and performance.

Synopsis: Apache Cassandra has proven to be one of the best solutions for storing and retrieving time series data at high velocity and high volume. This talk will discuss how the storage model of Cassandra is ideal for time series use cases and go over examples of how to best build data models. We will also cover pairing Apache Spark with Apache Cassandra to create a real time data analytics platform. Attendees will leave this session knowing how to build their own real time data analytics platform, and will be shocked at how easy it is!
name: Apache Cassandra, Apache Spark and Hadoop Meetup

description:
The introduction of Big Data and Hadoop has resulted in a paradigm shift in the field of data analytics. New analytics opportunities also bring new challenges: analyzing unstructured data, exploiting social media, making fast decisions on massive data volumes and more. R is a flexible programming language designed to facilitate predictive data analysis, but unlocking the value of Big Data with R can be complex. Businesses are looking for ways to remove this complexity, and combine unstructured or semi-structured data for improved predictions and optimal performance.

Join us on November 18, 2014 as we explore ways to make predictive analytics with R more accessible to business users and discuss the solutions needed to capitalize on the promise of Big Data.

This event is FREE. Snacks/Refreshments will be provided.

Agenda

6:00 - 6:30 pm Registration/Dinner

6:30 – 7:30 pm Presentation and Discussion

· R and its growing popularity in the world of predictive analytics

· Challenges in scaling R with Big Data

· Big R and its seamless integration with Hadoop

7:30 - 7:45 pm Interactive Demo(s)

7:45 - 8:15 pm Questions/Next Steps

Please RSVP. Seats are limited. Parking is available in covered parking - approximate cost is $3.00.
name: Big Data Analytics with R

description:
Hadoop is becoming an established component in today’s data centers. But, still misconceptions exist about how it works, where its best suited, and what its capable of. Join us on November 18 for this special session with Dirk deRoos, the author of Hadoop for Dummies, as he explains the basic concepts of Hadoop at an introductory level.

Seating is limited, so please register soon.

http://amzn.to/1qnEv7p
name: Understanding the Foundations of Hadoop - an IBM Insight Encore Presentation

description:
Join us to talk about how to build scalable Internet of Things Applications using Cloud Foundry, Bluemix, Containers and Cloudant

Agenda:

6:00 - 6:20 PM Refreshments and networking

6:20 - 6:30 PMWelcome address and introduction to Internet of Things Animesh Singh

6:30 - 7:10 PMCrap. Our IoT Kitchen is Broken Talk by Renat Khasanshyn - CEO of Altoros Systems

7:10 - 8:00 PMUsing Bluemix, IBM Internet of Things Foundation Cloud and Cloudant for building scalable IoT apps Lightening talks by Animesh Singh, Syed Zaidi, Dwight Ford and Nicholas Vargas - Bluemix Team

1) Crap. Our IoT Kitchen is Broken”

This is a tale of raw data becoming a gourmet meal, served restaurant-style. I won't talk about silver bullets or unicorns. Instead, I will focus on the long path of data bits from devices and sensors to the consumer. Along the way we will identify 4 levels of IoT maturity. We will also look at an S&P 500 company en route through the journey of digital transformation using Docker containers, Cloud Foundry-based microservices and IoT-based business model.

About speaker:

Renat Khasanshyn is CEO of Altoros Systems and Venture Partner at Runa Capital. Employing one of the largest pools of Cloud Foundry engineering expertise on the market, Altoros brings “software assembly lines” and "data lakes" into organizations through training, deployment and integration of solutions offered by the Cloud Foundry ecosystem.

2) Using Bluemix, IBM Internet of Things Foundation Clous and Cloudant for building scalable IoT apps

What's all the buzz about Internet of Things (IoT)? What can be done with all that data? Come and see the demonstration of sensor data from a variety of devices ( Simulated sensor from IBM Internet of Things Cloud, Arduino with light sensor, RaspberryPi with temperature sensor)

Also see how the Sensor generated data is then made useful by storing in a Cloudant database and then performing analysis

About speakers:

Animesh Singh, Syed Zaidi, Dwight Ford and Nicholas Vargas are part of Bluemix Team, and leading several innovations on Open Source technologies like Cloud Foundry, OpenStack and Docker
name: Building scalable IoT apps using Cloud Foundry, Containers, Bluemix & Cloudant
group_name: Bay Area PaaS, Cloud Foundry & BlueMix Meetup

description:
This is an IBM sponsored Big Data meetup group. Geared towards developers, data scientists and all Big Data enthusiasts, our meetups provide an opportunity to work hands on with the solutions and tools in our Big Data platform.

Our Meetups typically include a 45-60 min (max) presentation that serves as an introduction and overview for a specific Big Data technology. It is followed by ~3 hours to collaborate with fellow developers and apply your Big Data skills. We provide a cloud environment that you can run through the browser of your laptop at NO cost to you. Our meetups are FREE.

Meetup topics include:

- Hadoop-based analytics

- Stream Computing

- Text Analytics

- Visualization and Discovery tools for Big Data

- Big Data App Development

- Deep dives into the technologies that makes big data processing possible

- Anything and everything about Big Data

Join us today for a hands on software development experience.
name: SQL on Hadoop - Hands-on

Check out the SQL on Hadoop white paper:http://www-01.ibm.com/common/ssi/cgi-bin/ssialias?subtype=WH&infotype=SA&appname=SWGE_SW_SW_USEN&htmlfid=SWW14019USEN&attachment=SWW14019USEN.PDF

Speaker:

Claus Samuelsen, IBM

Claus Samuelsen has many years experience within data management, and has for more than 3 years had big data as his primary focus area.Working with customers all over Europe devolping Hadoop based solutions in several industries from banking, insurance, healthcare to automotive and gaming.

.

--------

Title: Apache Cassandra & Apache Spark for Time Series Data (45 minutes)

Presenter: Patrick McFadin

Bio: Patrick McFadin is regarded as one of the experts of Apache Cassandra and data modeling techniques. As the Chief Evangelist for Apache Cassandra and consultant for DataStax, he has helped build some of the largest deployments in the world. Previous to DataStax, he was Chief Architect at Hobsons, an education services company. There, he spoke often on Web Application design and performance.

Synopsis: Apache Cassandra has proven to be one of the best solutions for storing and retrieving time series data at high velocity and high volume. This talk will discuss how the storage model of Cassandra is ideal for time series use cases and go over examples of how to best build data models. We will also cover pairing Apache Spark with Apache Cassandra to create a real time data analytics platform. Attendees will leave this session knowing how to build their own real time data analytics platform, and will be shocked at how easy it is!

------------

Title: Application Development with NoSQL in Platform Clouds

Presenter: Rene Meyer, IBM Berlin, Client Technical Professional
name: Apache Cassandra, Apache Spark and Hadoop Meetup

description:
In this meetup, I'll be sharing details of my recent experience deploying BigInsights (IBM's distribution of Hadoop) in a recent Customer Engagement.

I'll talk about the use cases and approach we took to bring Hadoop into their corporate environment and culture (hint: much more than just technology enablement). I'll also touch on GPFS - IBM's General Parallel File System which has its heritage from large scale grid computing applications. GPFS can be used as a drop-in alternative to HDFS and we'll talk about the reasons why GPFS was chosen.... and things we learned about that. Maybe do a bit of a demo too...

Beverages and light snacks will be served.
name: Lessons Learned: Real Deployment of Hadoop (with GPFS)

description:
Agenda

6:30pm - 7pm: Pre-meeting conversation, networking, light refreshments 7pm - 8:30pm: Presentation, Q&A

Abstract

hybris [y] is a software vendor specialized in multichannel ecommerce and product content management (PCM) software. hybris was founded in 1997 and got acquired by SAP in 2013 . Hybris is considered as a leader in the enterprise multichannel commerce and e-commerce market by industry analyst firms Forrester Research, Gartner and Ventana Research.

[y]aaS is a multi tenant cloud platform which allows everyone to easily develop, extend and sell commerce services and apps. [y]aaS is based on a steadily growing micro service architecture running on Cloud Foundry as foundation. All services within [y]aaS are exposed through a consistent RESTfull API. Beside the API [y]aas also includes a Marketplace for hybris services as well as 3rd party service, an On Demand Store Front and a Back office application, all running on Cloud Foundry.

In this talk we will share our experience developing such an architecture and how Cloud Foundry helped us to streamline and speed up our development. We will also touch certain aspects of the infrastructure built up around Cloud Foundry and our Micro Services, like Logging and Monitoring.

Speaker

René WelchesProduct Owner – PaaS Cloud Foundry at hybrisRené started with hybris last year in the On Demand Delivery area. This year René took over the Cloud Foundry topic within hybris. He and his team are not only setting up a Cloud Foundry practice within hybris but also contributing to the SAP Cloud Foundry initiative. If he is not working with Cloud Foundry he plays Capoeira, bikes throughout New York or tries to catch some of the few waves at Long Beach.
name: Commerce as a (Micro-) Service with Cloud Foundry

http://ibm.co/1w9PTL5

Join us and participate in an exclusive Big Data Developer Day hosted by the IBM Big Data team.

Big Data Developer Day follows the Big Data, Better World, a Transdisciplinary Studies Conference being held at Claremont University on November 21, 2014. The conference presents a unique all-day university conference featuring scientists and humanists, researchers and practitioners, faculty and students, from across the schools and disciplines at CGU and beyond. Panelists and invited speakers will address the question of "Big Data, Better World?" from different intellectual and professional vantage points. To register for the conference, go to this link: http://www.cgu.edu/bigdataconference

Open source Apache Hadoop is a great framework for distributed processing of large data sets. But there’s a difference between "playing" with Big Data versus solving real problems. The reality is that Hadoop alone might not be enough. Experience IBM’s enterprise-class Hadoop product, InfoSphere BigInsights, which enhances open source Hadoop with required enterprise capabilities including: analytics, visualization, security, standard SQL, enterprise HBase, developer/admin tools, learn about the role of Big Data in Motion, Big Data Exploration and more. This session will include interactive Big Data use case discussions, an overview of what is Big Data, live demonstrations of key Big Data components (Big Data at Rest, Big Data in Motion).

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B27SpLOOhWw

and, hands-on with Big Data using InfoSphere BigInsights Quick Start Edition and InfoSphere Streams Quick Start Edition with guidance from development experts. This is a unique opportunity to develop skills and learn about exciting technologies and techniques that you can immediately take back to your organization.

This event is FREE. Snacks and refreshments will be provided.

description:
Join our next Meetup on Tuesday, December 2nd, 2014 at 6pm in IBM Innovation Center Foster City. We'll be talking about Data Science and how it fits in the world of Big Data.

The discipline of data science has got new lease of life with the advent of Big Data technologies. Big Data technologies has brought in the promises of applicability of data Science principles on large volume of datasets covering different challenges like internal/external data with structured/unstructured semantics, real time/batch processing, various protocols of data access etc.. However the question remained in the mind of Data Scientists is whether they can still use their favorite tools like SQL, spreadsheets, R even in the era of Big Data.

Join us as we explore use of Data Science techniques like predictive analytics using the tools like SQL, spreadsheets and R on publicly available data sources.

Agenda6:00 - 6:30 pm Registration/Food & Beverage6:30 – 7:15 pm Presentation and Discussion - Typical Challenges and Process involved in Data Science activities involving large volume of strcutured/unstructured data sets - Challenges in scaling tools like excel, SQL and R with Big Data - Big R and its seamless integration with Hadoop and other tools in Hadoop ecosystem7:15 - 8:30 pm Hands-on lab8:30 - 8:45 pm Questions/Next Steps

Doors open at 6:00pm.
name: Data Science and Big Data

description:
IBM® Cloudant™ database service delivers high availability, elastic scalability and innovative mobile device synchronization. The Cloudant JSON cloud-based data service allows mobile and web developers to quickly and easily store and access the rapidly increasing amount of mobile data using an application programming interface (API) that is significantly easier to use than alternatives. Increasingly, developers have embraced NoSQL databases because of their flexibility, and JSON has become thepredominant NoSQL database technology for mobile and web app developers. This session consists of both presentations and hands-on lab exercises.

To guarantee your seat, register here and receive a confirmation.

This session introduces Cloudant and how it differs from other data management platforms. Key features are described, including Cloudant Query, MapReduce and integrated Lucene Search along with RESTful HTTP API.

Agenda

• NoSQL landscape

• Database as a service

• JSON primer

• Cloudant dashboard

• Replication

• RESTful APIs

• Primary indexes

• Cloudant query

• Secondary indexes or MapReduce

• Search indexes Accessing Cloudant from an application

This event is free. Complimentary refreshments including continental breakfast and lunch will be provided. For your convenience, registration and continental breakfast begins at 8:30 a.m. The session starts at 9:00 a.m. and ends at approximately 5:00 p.m.

To guarantee your seat, register here and receive a confirmation.
name: A Technical Introduction to Cloudant : A JSON Data Layer in the Cloud

Software development is fundamental to your company’s ability to innovate and innovation is the key to staying out ahead of your competition. IBM is investing in the technologies you need to be agile and effective as a developer and we’re making them easily accessible as cloud services. Please join IBM for an interactive session that is sure to get your creative juices flowing.

Topics include:Cloudant scalable NoSQL cloud database service – Cloudant, the world’s first globally distributed database-as-a-service (DBaaS) for operational application data enables developers to quickly create next-generation apps. Companies of all sizes use Cloudant to manage data for large or fast growing web and mobile apps in ecommerce, online education, gaming, financial services, networking, and other industries.

IBM Bluemix is an open-standards, cloud-based platform for building, managing and running apps and services of all types (web, mobile, big data, new smart devices). Capabilities include Java, mobile backend development, application monitoring, as well as capabilities from ecosystem partners and open source — all through an as-a-service model in the cloud.

And for those who want to get their hands on this exciting technology, stick around for…Bluemix Hands-On Workshop: Take the opportunity to build and deploy applications and services like DevOps and Data in a matter of hours on Bluemix (built on SoftLayer)! Bluemix developers will be on hand to help you learn the fundamentals of building and deploying your application in the Cloud.

description:
NYC Bluemix Meetup Launch! Join us in New York City on December 16th for our first of many NYC IBM Bluemix Meetups! This Meetup will provide an introductory overview of the IBM Bluemix platform and offer hands on experience. The Meetup kicks off with an opportunity for networking at 5:30pm with food and beverages.

Using IBM Bluemix, an open-standards, cloud-based developer platform for building, managing and running apps, we will discuss how Bluemix offers you all the instant services, runtimes, and infrastructure you need to push your ideas for the future into the present.

Location: Midtown NYC (Grand Central vicinity) register to see address.

Agenda

5:30pm: Networking/Food & Beverages

6:00pm: Welcome and Announcements

6:15pm: Bluemix Overview & Q&A, Tim Vanderham

7:15pm: Break

7:30pm: Bluemix Hands-on Live & Q&A, Daniel Julin

8:30pm: Wrap-up

8:45pm: Networking

9:00pm: End of Meeting

If you plan to participate in the hands-on session, please bring your laptop. Get a head start by registering at ibm.biz/bluemixnyc and bring your logon info to the Meetup.

Speaker Bios:

Tim Vanderham is the Vice President responsible for the world wide development, delivery, operations, and support of the IBM Bluemix Platform and IBM Cloud Marketplace. IBM Bluemix is IBM's PaaS Platform based on open source technology and focused on delivery speed and agility to developers and a lower operational cost model to clients. In his current role, Tim is also responsible for the development and integration of the IBM Cloud Marketplace. As part of IBM's Cloud Leadership team, Tim collaborates closely with organizations across SWG, STG, and GTS to deliver the integrated capabilities for on-prem and off-prem dynamic cloud offerings across the variety of delivery models and technology choices available from IBM. Immediately prior to his current role, Tim was the Director of Development for PureApplication where he lead a world wide team that created and delivered the PureApplication technology to market. Prior to that role, he held a number of management roles within the WebSphere development organization spanning support and services through development and delivery. In all of his roles, he is very active in the technical and public community through conferences and his close work with clients worldwide.

Daniel Julin is the Technical Area Lead for the Bluemix Developer Support and Enablement Team. He focuses on delivering a great support experience for Customers developing and running applications on Bluemix and leading various initiatives to construct serviceability tools and functions for the Bluemix platform. Prior to his involvement with Bluemix, Daniel spent 25 years developing and troubleshooting various complex online and distributed systems, ranging from WebSphere Application Server, TxSeries/Encina transaction processing, reliable distributed systems, to the Mach operating system kernel

description:
NOTE: This meetup is located at Hack/Reduce on Third Street in Cambridge

Join Us: Big Data hack night at Hack/Reduce on Tuesday, 12/16 from 6-9. Hear about the new Big Data for Social Good Challenge, share ideas, and work on your project.

More on the Big Data for Social Good Challenge.....

CALLING ALL DEVELOPERS .... JOIN THE BIG DATA FOR SOCIAL GOOD CHALLENGE

Big data exists in just about everything we use and do. It comes from phones, cars, roads, power lines, waterways, food crates, and innumerable other items you’d never think of as computers. This data speaks volumes about our collective behavior and society – so let’s use it to do something incredible! IBM invites developers and data enthusiasts to take a deep dive into real world civic issues using big data and the IBM Bluemix Analytics for Hadoop service. Analyze one of our curated datasets or bring your own! Use Hadoop and your data to create a clickable and interactive data visualization to highlight insights that you’ve found.

Ready to get started? $40,000 in prizes will be awarded....

Don't forget to register for the Big Data for Social Good Challenge: " class="linkified">http://ibmhadoop.challengepost.com;

" class="linkified">

Subject: "Powered by Watson" Best Practices Webcast

To attend the meeting:1) See the visuals: https://join.me/IBMWatson(presenter will start the session 10 minutes prior to the start time) 2) Listen to the audio (dial the phone number and enter the access code):

United States - New York, NY [masked]Access Code[masked]#

International dial in numbers available athttps://join.me/intphone/793363799/0

Computer instructions:On a computer, use any browser with Flash. Nothing to download.On a phone or tablet, launch the join.me app (https://join.me/app) and enter meeting code: IBMWatson

You're invited to attend the first Watson Ecosystem Community Webcast: Best Practices for Building a "Powered by Watson" ApplicationThursday, December 18, 2014 at 12:00 PM eastern time.

Speaker: Chris Ackerson, Watson Ecosystem Solution Architect

Abstract:New Watson Ecosystem partners often ask us "what are some tips and proven approaches for building a Powered by Watson application?"

We've pooled a year's worth of learnings from our Solution Architects working with dozens of Ecosystem partners to assemble a set of best practices and lessons learned for building the next generation of cognitive apps. In this webcast, a command performance from the technical breakout track at the Ecosystem at Scale event in New York on October 7, 2014, we will offer tips and guidance spanning the entire Powered by Watson development life cycle - from content acquisition, optimization and administration to application architecture and design, to training, testing and lexical expansion.

This session will cover key topics including:* The impact of the user interaction model on application architecture* The use of Watson design elements to create a cognitive user experience* Approaches to identify content sources* Planning for the full content life cycle* Using content to expand the user interaction model* Creation of ground truth* Building an iterative train and test strategy* Understanding error analysis

There will also be time for interactive questions and answers. For those who cannot attend, this session will be recorded.

Mark your calendars! An invitation with registration instructions will follow early next week.

Thursday, December 18, 2014 at 12:00 PM eastern time.

description:
Agenda

6pm - 6:30pm: Pre-meeting conversation and networking, pizza and drinks will be provided.6:30pm - 8pm: Presentation, Q&A

Abstract

Dave Nielsen will share experience derived from bringing several “software factories” into large organizations through deployment and integration of solutions offered by the Cloud Foundry ecosystem.

Expect to get answers from each of the seven categories of questions asked by our customers who are evaluating or implementing Cloud Foundry:

• Adoption. Can you show me examples of real-world deployments at large (5k+ employees) organizations?

• Money. Do you have business cases on Cloud Foundry that make ROI hard to argue?

• Deployment. Can you show me a deployment topology for a typical production cluster? What do Cloud Foundry clusters running on AWS and OpenStack look like? How do you size the cluster?

• Mechanics. What is going on "under the hood" in a Cloud Foundry cluster?

• Administration. Can you show the admin tools you use? What are the responsibilities of an operator?

• Apps & developer adoption. What are the seven characteristics of applications that run on Cloud Foundry without modifications?

• Experience. What did you learn from operating several clusters in production?

Speaker: Dave Nielsen, Cloud Computing Evangelist & Consultant

By day, Dave is a consultant helping firms engage with influential leaders in the developer & DevOps communities. He is particularly fascinated by Cloud Computing APIs and Platforms. By night, is the founder of CloudCamp, a community of 50,000 disruptive cloud enthusiasts and community organizers in 100+ cities around the world. Follow Dave on Twitter @davenielsen.

PARKING·  We are located at 1 Rogers Street Cambridge, MA which is a U shaped building positioned between Edwin H. Land Blvd and 1st Street. The sign on the front of the building states "Charles Park" which can sometimes confuse guests. The auditorium is on the first floor.· Parking is located across the street at the Cambridgeside Galleria Mall located at 100 Cambridgeside Place. We can validate guest parking for a discounted rate if they are parked for longer than 5 hours (price drops from $20 to $11). · Below is a map that shows where the mall is in relation to the center. Once guests park their cars, they will take the elevator/escalator to the first floor of the mall. They will walk towards the end of the mall where the Cheesecake Factory and California Pizza Kitchen are located. The center is in the building directly across the street. Guests will have to walk along the side of the building, until they reach Rogers Street. From there, they will turn right and the front doors are located directly ahead.

PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION· Lechmere Station (Green Line): Located .4 miles from center which is an 8 minute walk.· Kendall Square (Red Line): Located .8 miles from the center which is a 15 minute walk. The Cambridgeside Galleria Shuttle to and from Kendall Square runs every 20 minutes from 9AM to 8PM Monday through Sunday.
name: Cloud Foundry in Production: Use Cases, Limitations, Lessons Learned

description:
This is a new thing we're gonna try.

Each time we do this meetup, we'll start with this Big Data and Hadoop Introductory session because we're getting new people all the time and we want a "standard way" to get them up to speed.

This will be a 1 hour session and content will be the same every time.

Immediately following these intro sessions, we'll dive deeper into a topic related to Big Data and Hadoop.

If you're just getting started with Big Data, this session is for you.

Location to be determined, but it will be downtown Vancouver.
name: Big Data and Hadoop - Just the Basics

description:
VERY Excited to have Benjamin Leonhardi confirmed for our Deeper Dive session (see Bio below), which immediately follows our "Big Data and Hadoop - Basics" session.

If you have some Knowledge of Hadoop and want to learn HBASE (which runs on Hadoop) - we created this for you. AND, we're going to get hands on... so bring your laptops.

If you are new to Hadoop, you should attend the 6pm session for a primer as a pre-requisite for and this session.

Location: Almost confirmed - but will be downtown Vancouver.

Meetup Description:

HBase is a (open source), massively scalable, NoSQL distributed database that runs on HDFS. In this session we will give an introduction to its architecture and the main differences to traditional database systems. HBase was designed to solve traditional database problems like scalability, high-availability, and an easy integration with applications. We will discuss use-cases and give a small overview over competing NoSQL technologies.

Attendees will get hands-on with software provided to learn how to create and populate tables and how to query them. You will learn the basics of HBase table modelling and get an a quick introduction into the use of BigSQL over HBase.

Agenda:

7pm - 8:15 pm: HBase Presentation- Introduction to HBase- Use cases- Architecture- Competing Technologies- BigSQL over HBase- Q&A

8:15 - 9 pm: Hands-on lab

If you want to do the lab, you need to prep:

Please download the BigInsights Quickstart image ( Link InfoSphere BigInsights Quick Start Edition VMware Image on the right side ). You may need 7zip to unpack it and VMWare Player to run it. We will distribute the lab files in the meetup. http://www-01.ibm.com/software/data/infosphere/biginsights/quick-start/

Speaker Bio:

Benjamin Leonhardi is a BigData Specialist for IBM Canada. He is an expert in Hadoop, parallel databases, and streaming solutions. Before that he was the team lead for the BigData/Warehousing partner enablement team. He started out as a Software Developer at the IBM Research And Development Lab in Boeblingen, Germany. There he was a developer in the data mining, text mining, and mining reporting solutions.
name: HBASE - Intro and Hands On... (Session 1)

description:
Including; Hackathon Announcement: IBM's Big Data for Social Good Challenge

The ability to use data from public domain sources has been an exciting prospect for BI and Web Developers both in the commercial and public sector space. Of late, an increasing number of Hackathons and "Challenges" have been presented both by Academic and Commercial entities where the collaboration of designers, developers, testers, and users can come together to help learn as well as provide solutions.Our meetup this month will feature a few developers who have used open data sources to provide their examples (we are still open to any others who would like to present)! Finally, IBM will discuss their "Big Data for Social Good Challenge". The challenge offers prizes for developers ranging from $1,000 through $20,000 in cash, along with the opportunity to earn a donation in your name to Plantabilion.org (Nature Conservancy).Presenters (Subject to Change):Dan Zubey - Solomon Communications Systems - A public safety communications engineer, Dan has created a notification and mapping system based off of publicly-available Phoenix Fire Department data, that geolocates fire calls, maps them, and creates notification events in the background.Greg Morgan - Maricopa County - Greg has a lot of experience working with OpenStreetMap and other public data sources to present and analyze data. He will talk about a few of the projects he's worked on in his spare time (outside working hours).Joe Junker - IBM - Joe will give us an overview of the Big Data for Social Good Challenge & a few of the tools IBM is allowing free access for developers to compete for these prizes
name: Open Data, Hackathons & Challenge Announcement

description:
Register to attend IBM Design Thinking Meetup, Join the first of 5 part series to learn the basics on 1/20/15. https://ibm.biz/DesignMeetups

Solving real problems for real people and employing hypotheses testing will help you make every development dollar count. User Experience Design techniques, or design thinking, can help you gain deep insights into your users and their pain points. Join this 5 part series to learn the basics.

Empathy - Gaining Insight Into Your UserThis first Meet-up will provide an overview of design, how it can impact your business, and a deep-dive into the first step - Empathy Maps. Empathy Maps are used by UX (User Experience) designers to understand how their users feel in any given situation, and how that situation fits into the context of their users' lives. Without this, we are aiming in the dark or filling in the gaps with our own ideas and hoping we're right. Join us as we provide you with the tools to understand your user so you can deliberately develop your offering with insight and confidence.

6:30 pm - 7:00 pm Food and Networking

7:00 pm - 8:30 pm Presentation and Demo
name: Making Your Development Count Through Design - A Series For The Not Designer

Join us in New York City on January 21st for our second of many NYC IBM Bluemix Meetups! If you want to know more about Watson or are thinking about how to power your cognitive applications, join us at this Meetup. We will provide an introductory overview of the Watson Services for IBM Bluemix, offer hands on experience, and give participants a chance to discuss their ideas. The Meetup kicks off with an opportunity for networking at 5:30pm with food and beverages.

IBM Bluemix is an open-standards, cloud-based developer platform for building, managing and running apps. In October 2014, IBM announced the opening of the Watson Developer Cloud to anyone with a Bluemix account. You can read more about the announcement on developerWorks https://developer.ibm.com/bluemix/2014/10/08/watson-on-bluemix/

Location: IBM 590 Madison Avenue, NYC.

To get the most out of the meetup - REGISTER FOR BLUEMIX: http://ibm.biz/NYC_Meetup

Speaker Bios:

Nathan Vega joined the Bluemix team earlier this year with the primary focus of engaging the Bluemix developer community and providing relevant content that will help developers realize their ideas on the platform. Nathan joined the team after being a Market Manager and Strategist for the Watson Platform. In this role, he helped define a Watson platform and tooling solution that will power an era of cognitive computing applications built by IBM partners. Nathan started his 13 year IBM career as a JAVA Developer building WebSphere Portal Server.

Nathan holds an Executive MBA from The Ohio State University and a BS in Computer Science from the University of Cincinnati.

Speaker

Nathan Vega joined the Bluemix team earlier this year with the primary focus of engaging the Bluemix developer community and providing relevant content that will help developers realize their ideas on the platform. Nathan joined the team after being a Market Manager and Strategist for the Watson Platform. In this role, he helped define a Watson platform and tooling solution that will power an era of cognitive computing applications built by IBM partners. Nathan started his 13 year IBM career as a JAVA Developer building WebSphere Portal Server.

Nathan holds an Executive MBA from The Ohio State University and a BS in Computer Science from the University of Cincinnati.

description:
It is estimated that over 80% of enterprise data is unstructured and most organizations have no way to capture and analyze it. There is a need to build applications for big data that provide continuous ingestion and analysis of information from emerging sources such as GPS, video, social media, audio, and machine and sensor data. Enterprises are looking for ways to analyze data in motion to empower decision making and deliver real-time responses, without the need to store data.

Please join us on Wednesday, January 21, 2015 for an interactive session on capturing and analyzing big data in motion. This Meetup will include an informative discussion on real-time, streaming data and sample use cases, as well as a demonstration in which we will ask you to participate. So bring your smartphone or tablet if you would like to be part of the action! We will show how applications can quickly ingest and correlate information, as it arrives from real-time sources, and enables faster and smarter decision making.

Space is limited so sign up today.
name: Big Data in Motion: Extracting Insight from Real-time, Streaming Data

description:
ABSTRACT

IBM dashDB is a new data warehousing solution on the cloud which allows the user to visualize their data and perform data analysis through built-in analytics, R predictive modeling and other BI and ETL tools.

Design thinking is defined as combining empathy for the context of a problem, creativity in the generation of insights and solutions, and rationality in analyzing and fitting various solutions to the problem context.

In this meetup learn more about design thinking, and how it is being used to improve dashDB.

AGENDA:

WELCOME (6:00 - 6:25pm)

LET'S THINK TOGETHER (6:25pm - 6:45pm)

INTRO TO DESIGN THINKING (6:45pm- 7:15pm)

- Use case scenario example : IBM dashDB

- Description of the Design Thinking steps

HANDS-ON WORK IN GROUPS (7:15pm - 8:30pm)

Discussion: who do you think would benefit from using dashDB? · Brainstorm: what does this user want to achieve with this app? how can we make their experience great?

A step by step walk through to create personas, use cases and empathy maps to help empathize with users and design apps to better suit their needs

PRESENTER'S BIOS:

Maria Attarian

Maria is a software engineer working for IBM Canada Ltd. She is currently working on IBM dashDB, a role that required direct learning and application of all the principles of Design Thinking upon a real software product, within a fast pace environment based on continuous delivery and Agile development

Helen Kontozopoulos

Helen is a design thinking strategist who advises early stage startups on crafting software and hardware companies with design thinking, anthropology, marketing and lean startup business development tools. As a Co-Founder and General Partner of SMART LAUNCH she is integral in creating Canada's top seed funding and startup program for early-stage Internet of Things (IoT) & Artificial Intelligence (AI) companies which come out of Canadian universities.She is the Director and Co-Founder of the technology conference, SMARTWEEK 2014/2015, an Internet of Things and Artificial Intelligence conference based in Toronto with Global partnered events.Helen is a Lecturer at the University of Toronto, in the Department of Computer Science, where she teaches lean startup methodologies, design thinking and business innovation. She is on the UofT/IBM Watson teaching team.

Anna Kop

Anna is a user experience designer, applying principles of design thinking daily to improve healthcare apps. Feel free to reach out at @annakopster
name: An intro to IBM dashDB and design thinking

Tesla, BMW i8, they are very modern & fashion to cars, not only a new car, also a revolution for automotive industry.

But, there is a big gap to such electronic cars, "power provider".

Let's image, if those electronic cars can't get power as easy as fuel now for traditional cars, the revolution couldn't go further.

It will must be happened in the near future. We can be sure that millions of "power provider" lied on the roads, which "power provider" will provide easy, fast service to cars. There are many business opportunities to us. How to manage such a lot of "power provider"? What kind of value-added service we can find out?

We could meet-up and find the appropriate services which can host in cloud service.

e.g. Create a manage system for "power provider", and can listen every "power provider" node status, to schedule a maintenance plan.

It's brand new business for every company, and it's a "blue sea".

Let's discover the chance and take advantage.

description:
IBM® Cloudant™ database service delivers high availability, elastic scalability and innovative mobile device synchronization. The Cloudant JSON cloud-based data service allows mobile and web developers to quickly and easily store and access the rapidly increasing amount of mobile data using an application programming interface (API) that is significantly easier to use than alternatives. Increasingly, developers have embraced NoSQL databases because of their flexibility, and JSON has become thepredominant NoSQL database technology for mobile and web app developers. This session consists of both presentations and hands-on lab exercises.

To guarantee your seat, register here and receive a confirmation.

This session introduces Cloudant and how it differs from other data management platforms. Key features are described, including Cloudant Query, MapReduce and integrated Lucene Search along with RESTful HTTP API.

Agenda

• NoSQL landscape

• Database as a service

• JSON primer

• Cloudant dashboard

• Replication

• RESTful APIs

• Primary indexes

• Cloudant query

• Secondary indexes or MapReduce

• Search indexes Accessing Cloudant from an application

This event is free. Complimentary refreshments including continental breakfast and lunch will be provided. For your convenience, registration and continental breakfast begins at 8:30 a.m. The session starts at 9:00 a.m. and ends at approximately 5:00 p.m.

To guarantee your seat, register here and receive a confirmation.
name: A Technical Introduction to Cloudant : A JSON Data Layer in the Cloud

description:
Target audience and skill level: Beginner to intermediate Computer Science / ICTAbsolute beginner in Biology / Cancer

Abstract: We've heard it in the news: Today's advances in genomics can revolutionize the health care industry; however, what is not that often known, are the details about how the data is captured and manipulated, the size and types of these big data, and the need for privacy. In this presentation our guest speaker, Michael Moorhouse will give us an insight into the world of bioinformatics, and the current efforts underway to use it to predict, treat and cure diseases focusing on cancer.

Agenda:

6:00pm - 6:15pmIntroduction to Biology, DNA Sequencing machines, Cancer and 'personalised medicine'.

6:15pm - 6:20pmAbout OICR (Ontario Insitute for Cancer Research): Mission, history and future

6:20pm - 7:00pmDescribing the general computational infrastructure used: locally and abroad.

7:00pm - 7:15pm: Break

7:15pm - 8:00pmDemonstrations and Q&A

Biography of the speaker (in his own words):

Michael MoorhouseI’m a Bioinformatician – a mixture of Biology, computer science and mathematics. My undergraduate degree is in ‘Biochemistry’ and having started programming computers aged eight I did my Masters degree in Bioinformatics because the overlap of the fields interested me. I’ve worked in the Netherlands, my home country of the UK and in Canada on a range of topics in the field of Bioscience and medical research for the past few years. Most of these involved ‘data munging’ to interface pre-existing tools and packages to my own software or filtering strategies. Quite quickly I became interested in Data Management: better management = less munging & better results with less pain. I have spent a lot of my time more recently assisting with the storage, transfer and security of the newer ‘Genomics’ data – specifically resulting from High Throughput DNA Sequencing - between international databases or consortia. My current roll is that of ‘Automation Engineer’ – aka. ‘Data Manager’ – at the OICR. Here I and the team are responsible safe and secure keeping of ~2 PB of data with a typical data set being in the ~20-50TB range
name: Managing & Processing Big Data for Cancer Genomics, an insight of Bioinformatics

description:
The IBM Rochester Technical Vitality Council invites you to attend a hands on 1.5 hour Meetup on February 18, 2015 from 4:00 to 5:30 pm at the University of Minnesota Rochester in room 419. The topic for this Meetup will be: Cloud, Mobile, and Cognitive Computing Application Development using IBM's Bluemix cloud platform. This is not a sales meeting. Instead, IBM would like to make Bluemix available to as many technical developers as possible, free of charge. We would also like to provide an opportunity for technical developers in the Rochester area to collaborate and interact around this new service. There may be some time at the end to do some coding, so bring your laptop. Also, it will make things easier if you sign up for Bluemix prior to the Meetup at http://bit.ly/1EMwq3A.

What is BlueMix, exactly?

Bluemix is an open-standards, cloud-based platform for building, managing and running apps of all types (web, mobile, big data, new smart devices). Capabilities include support for multiple programming languages and runtimes including Java and Node.js, mobile backend development, application monitoring, as well as capabilities from ecosystem partners and open source — all through an as-a-service model in the cloud. To find out more information, go to the Bluemix website at http://bit.ly/1EMwq3A.

Hopefully you will want to join us for this exciting opportunity to "Meetup" with technical IBMers and other technical people in Rochester. We look forward to meeting with you soon.
name: Learn about IBM's new free cloud development platform, BlueMix

description:
The bigger your data, the bigger the problem if it is somehow lost. Hadoop, by default, helps with data redundancy/HA. In this presentation, Rakesh, as an expert in IBM BigInsights (IBM's Hadoop Distribution), will provide a perspective on the importance of understanding where open source and IBM tools/features store their data in the cluster, what are the prominent big data solutions for backup and DR, the major components in BigInsights that need to be backed up and why, and some specifics on implementing backup/DR solutions within BigInsights.

About the Presenter: Rakish Naik is currently a Big Data Technical Solution Specialist with IBM Americas. Rakesh has worked more than 20 years in IT in various roles, including a 4gl/C/Web developer, Informix DBA, System Admin, Advanced Support Engineer (Informix/DB2), and Technical Account Manager (Informix/DB2/Netezza). More recently, Rakesh worked as a Partner Enablement Specialist, where I developed and delivered Big Data (BigInsights/Streams/Watson Explorer/IPDA) bootcamps to IBM partners around the world, including assistance with system review, porting, and implementation activities.Social / Networking: 6:30-7:10pmPresentation: 7:10pm - 8:30pm
name: Backup and Disaster Recovery in Hadoop

description:
Agenda:

6:30 - 7:00 PM Networking

7:00 - 8:30 PM Presentation Clinical Hub and the path to Cognitive

8:30 - 9:00 PM Networking

IBM speakers:

Scott Schumacher, IBM Distinguished Engineer, Chief Scientist (overview and demo),

Tanveer Syeda-Mahmood, Research Scientist, IBM Research Almaden Lab (deep dive).

Life Sciences companies, CRO's, hospitals and other research organizations can utilize operational analytics to help improve results for the identification of study subjects, treatment and outcomes analysis, rare event detections, resource utilization and cost comparative effectiveness research.

Scott and Tanveer will discuss the following:

- How the structured and unstructured data is captured throughout the enterprise

- How to build the complete and TRUSTED longitudinal person record for analysis and research

- How to encrypt identity information to protect the person's privacy

- How to normalize and analyze the person information to identify similarities across a range of criteria

- Demo the easy to use search capabilities and results for faster analysis

- Discuss the path to Cognitive.
name: Clinical Research improvements with Big Data/Analytics and the path to Cognitive

We are looking for a venue! Please contact me with suggestions!

name: Welcome to Data savvy, Insight driven, Big Data Meetup on 27th February

description:
Hands-on lab for BigData and Analytics services using IBM Bluemix (PaaS). Admission free. (Re-run for Dec 2014)

Door opens at 14:00

Agenda:

14:30-14:50

1) IBM BigData and Analytics Strategy in Bluemix (20min)

14:50-17:30

2) Hands-on labs (160min)

-Analytics for Hadoop on Bluemix-Create a business intelligence and analytics service in Ruby with Analytics Warehouse on IBM Bluemix-Build a data mining app using Java, Weka, and the Analytics Warehouse service-Leverage IBM Cognos on IBM Bluemix using the Embeddable Reporting service

---------------------------------------------------------

Prerequisites:

Presentation is conducted in Japanese. (Hands-on materials are in Engligh)

1) Please submit your attendance request to attend the meetup.

https://ibm.biz/BdEQPP

2) Prior to the meetup, you need to have a free-trial account for IBM Bluemix which is effective for 30 days. Please create the account after Feb 1, so you will be able to use it on Feb 27 without being expired. Sign up from the URL below:

https://ibm.biz/BdESeP

IBM Innovation Center Tokyo Access:

https://www-304.ibm.com/partnerworld/wps/servlet/ContentHandler/pw_com_prb_iic_access

https://www.ibm.com/partnerworld/wps/servlet/RedirectServlet?cmsId=pw_ast_prb_iic_accessmapeng&attachmentName=en_map.pdf
name: BigData and Analytics Lab

description:
IBM® Bluemix™ is an open-standards, cloud-based platform for building, managing, and running apps of all types, such as web, mobile, big data, and smart devices. Capabilities include Java, mobile back-end development, and application monitoring, as well as features from ecosystem partners and open source—all provided as-a-service in the cloud.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZR_jDitw0Sc

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FUDOsBDAahE

Agenda:

02.00 PM -02: 30 AM: Registration

2.30 PM - 3.00 PM : Introduction to Bluemix

3. 00 PM - 4:00 PM - Live Demo & Hands on

4.15 PM - 4.45 PM : Networking

4.45PM - 6.00 PM: Q&A & wrapup
name: IBM Bluemix Meetup - Dayananda Sagar College of Engineering
group_name: Bangalore PaaS, IBM Bluemix and Cloud Computing Meetup

description:
Bluemix Meetup:

Bluemix Advantage (10:00 - 12:00): Developers and business leaders alike will benefit from hearing how Bluemix and SoftLayer offer a low-risk, secure, cost sensitive environment - using new capabilities and technologies geared towards the cloud. Take advantage of the opportunity to learn how to differentiate and leap-frog your competition with IBM Bluemix and SoftLayer.
name: Learn about IBM's cloud development platform, Bluemix

description:
Bluemix Meetup:

Bluemix Hands-On Workshops (12:30 - 17:00): Take the opportunity to build and deploy applications and services like DevOps and Data in a matter of hours on Bluemix (built on SoftLayer)! As part of this workshop you will be able to: Learn the fundamentals of building and deploying your application in the Cloud (Bluemix DevOps Services) Work with Bluemix experts on how to use the product and migrate your application Help shape Bluemix with your input and feedback.

Get prepared and get online with IBM Bluemix by registering for free: https://ibm.biz/BluemixDayNL
name: Develop and Deploy Applications in the Cloud Using IBM Bluemix PaaS

description:
THE BIG DATA FOR SOCIAL GOOD CHALLENGE BEGINS NOVEMBER 10, 2014 AND CONTINUES TO MARCH 3, 2015.

CALLING ALL DEVELOPERS .... JOIN THE BIG DATA FOR SOCIAL GOOD CHALLENGE

Big data exists in just about everything we use and do. It comes from phones, cars, roads, power lines, waterways, food crates, and innumerable other items you’d never think of as computers. This data speaks volumes about our collective behavior and society – so let’s use it to do something incredible! IBM invites developers and data enthusiasts to take a deep dive into real world civic issues using big data and the IBM Bluemix Analytics for Hadoop service. Analyze one of our curated datasets or bring your own (provided it meets these requirements)! Use Hadoop and your data to create a clickable and interactive data visualization to highlight insights that you’ve found.

Ready to get started? $40,000 in prizes will be awarded....

Register here:http://ibmhadoop.challengepost.com/

What to Create: Participants must create a working, clickable, and interactive data visualization utilizing the Analytics for Hadoop service on IBM Bluemix.

Data Requirements: Your data visualization must analyze one or more datasets included in the curated list of datasets on the Data page OR meet the data size, content, and licensing requirements described on the Data page. The total size of the Datasets analyzed must be between 500MB - 7GB in size.

Check out the requirements then go get your IBM Bluemix extended promo code and check out the datasets!

description:
Register to attend IBM Design Thinking Meetup, Join the Third of Four part series to learn the basics on 3/3/15. http://ibm.biz/DesignMeetups2

In this session we will use the pain points from session 2 as the basis for our discussion around defining a minimum viable product. We will discuss how to weigh the different factors, including desired business outcomes, capturing target market, and generating revenue, on the same scale as the "ideal"product for a user. We will also talk about using hypotheses testing as a tool for gathering data in order to drive business and design decisions, and be super responsive to the. needs of both the business and the end-user.

Did you miss the other sessions? Don't worry! It is very easy to catch up and follow along.

6:30 pm - 7:00 pm Food and Networking

7:00 pm - 8:30 pm Presentation and Demo
name: Minimum Viable Product MVP & Hypotheses Testing

IBM invites developers and data enthusiasts to take a deep dive into real world civic issues using big data and the IBM Bluemix Analytics for Hadoop service. Analyze one of our curated datasets or bring your own (provided it meets these requirements)! Use Hadoop and your data to create a clickable and interactive data visualization to highlight insights that you’ve found.

Ready to get started? $40,000 in prizes will be awarded....

Register here:http://ibmhadoop.challengepost.com/

What to Create: Participants must create a working, clickable, and interactive data visualization utilizing the Analytics for Hadoop service on IBM Bluemix.

Data Requirements: Your data visualization must analyze one or more datasets included in the curated list of datasets on the Data page OR meet the data size, content, and licensing requirements described on the Data page. The total size of the Datasets analyzed must be between 500MB - 7GB in size.

Check out the requirements then go get your IBM Bluemix extended promo code and check out the datasets!

description:
Discover IBM Big Data & Analytics and get fresh insights.

Register at: https://ibm.biz/BdECkW Key concepts: Open Cloud with IBM Bluemix, Cloudant DBaaS, Hadoop and MapReduce, Building the Analytics layer with SPSS and R Detail:

Capture the time-value of data and act with confidence. The Hands-on Workshop - designed for developers and includes demonstrations and hands-on labs built on Bluemix. Details showing the architecture behind the solution being demonstrated, Open Cloud environment with IBM Bluemix, Connected devices, Utilization of Cloudant DBaaS, Hadoop and MapReduce, Building the Analytics layer with SPSS and R will be covered. We welcome business types and executives that are interested in a deeper dive of Big Data & Analytics Cloud offerings.

Register on https://ibm.biz/BdECkW prior to the event and become familiar with Bluemix at ibm.biz/BluemixATX to have a deeper experience at the event.Highlights Include:Architecture of the solutionOpen Cloud environment withWednesday, March 4, 2015

IBM BluemixConnected devicesUsage of Bluemix services, Cloudant DBaaS and HadoopBuilding the Analytics layer with SPSSHands on Lab (attendees can choose from a selection of Bluemix based labs)SPSS demoExtending the demo scenarioSign up the Hands-on Workshop to learn about key capabilities and how the IBM Big Data & Analytics portfolio can help you solve real business problems. IBM will be providing lunch.
name: IBM - Big Data & Analytics workshop with hands on lab

description:
In diesem Webcast gebe ich Ihnen einen kurzen Überblick über IBM Bluemix, die PaaS-Cloud-Plattform von IBM.

Anschliessend zeige ich Ihnen in einer Live-Demo, wie man mit Bluemix-Mitteln Twitter-Nachrichten in Hadoop ablegen und mit Watson-Methoden analysieren kann, alles in ca 10 Minuten und ohne irgend etwas zu programmieren.

Interessiert? Dann melden Sie sich einfach hier an, kostenlos und unverbindlich: https://ibm.biz/BdE5LzSie erhalten dann umgehend die Infos zum Webcast.

If you are interested in this topic but would need the ecvent in English language please let me know. If there are enough candidates, I will schedule an English version.
name: Live-Demo: End-to-End Twitter-Analyse mit Hadoop und Watson in 10 Min

description:
Tesla, BMW i8, they are very modern & fashion to cars, not only a new car, also a revolution for automotive industry.

But, there is a big gap to such electronic cars, "power provider".

Let's image, if those electronic cars can't get power as easy as fuel now for traditional cars, the revolution couldn't go further.

It will must be happened in the near future. We can be sure that millions of "power provider" lied on the roads, which "power provider" will provide easy, fast service to cars. There are many business opportunities to us. How to manage such a lot of "power provider"? What kind of value-added service we can find out?

We could meet-up and find the appropriate services which can host in cloud service.

e.g. Create a manage system for "power provider", and can listen every "power provider" node status, to schedule a maintenance plan.

It's brand new business for every company, and it's a "blue sea".

Let's discover the chance and take advantage.
name: Cloud Service to smart electronic cars industry
group_name: Chengdu PaaS and Bluemix Computing Meetup

description:
This meetup has been set up in support of our friends at IEEE Toronto. Two topics will be covered:

Topic 1: Semi-automated human genome annotation

Abstract: Sequence census methods like ChIP-seq now produce an unprecedented amount of genome-anchored data. We have developed an integrative method to identify patterns from multiple experiments simultaneously while taking full advantage of high-resolution data, discovering joint patterns across different assay types. We apply this method to ENCODE chromatin data for multiple human cell types, including ChIP-seq data on covalent histone modifications and transcription factor binding, and DNase-seq and FAIRE-seq readouts of open chromatin. In an unsupervised fashion, we identify patterns associated with transcription start sites, gene ends, enhancers, CTCF elements, and repressed regions. The method yields a model which elucidates the relationship between assay observations and functional elements in the genome. This model identifies sequences likely to affect transcription, and we verify these predictions in laboratory experiments. We have made software and an integrative genome browser track freely available (http://pmgenomics.ca/hoffmanlab/proj/segway/).

Speaker: Michael M. Hoffman (Assistant Professor in the Departments of Medical Biophysics and Computer Science, University of Toronto)

Topic #2: Deep Autoencoder Neural Networks for Gene Ontology Annotation Predictions

Abstract: The annotation of genomic information is a major challenge in biology and bioinformatics. Existing databases of known gene functions are incomplete and prone to errors, and the biomolecular experiments needed to improve these databases are slow and costly. While computational methods are not a substitute for experimental verification, they can help in two ways: algorithms can aid in the curation of gene annotations by automatically suggesting inaccuracies, and they can predict previously-unidentified gene functions, accelerating the rate of gene function discovery. In this work, we develop an algorithm that achieves both goals using deep autoencoder neural networks. With experiments on gene annotation data from the Gene Ontology project, we show that deep autoencoder networks achieve better performance than other standard machine learning methods, including the popular truncated singular value decomposition.

Speaker: Davide Chicco (postdoctoral fellow at the Princess Margaret Cancer Centre, University of Toronto)
name: Semi-automated human genome annotation

description:
IBM® Cloudant™ database service delivers high availability, elastic scalability and innovative mobile device synchronization. The Cloudant JSON cloud-based data service allows mobile and web developers to quickly and easily store and access the rapidly increasing amount of mobile data using an application programming interface (API) that is significantly easier to use than alternatives. Increasingly, developers have embraced NoSQL databases because of their flexibility, and JSON has become thepredominant NoSQL database technology for mobile and web app developers. This session consists of both presentations and hands-on lab exercises.

To guarantee your seat, register here and receive a confirmation.

This session introduces Cloudant and how it differs from other data management platforms. Key features are described, including Cloudant Query, MapReduce and integrated Lucene Search along with RESTful HTTP API.

• NoSQL landscape

• Database as a service

• JSON primer

• Cloudant dashboard

• Replication

• RESTful APIs

• Primary indexes

• Cloudant query

• Secondary indexes or MapReduce

• Search indexes Accessing Cloudant from an application

To guarantee your seat, register here and receive a confirmation.

Is there such a thing as "unstructured data" ? As a lot of us have learnt the hard way at school, even natural language has structural rules that must be obeyed.

At this meetup, we will explore the nature & various flavours of unstructured data, the challenges it raises for the developers & data scientist and its importance in the Big Data landscape. First, we will look at the "semi-structured data" field with an overview of JSON (one of its major representative), its use & impact on both the relational & NoSQL Big Data worlds, and what it means for the future of the industry and its practitionners. We will then dive into the area of free text, with a developer in the natural language processing field walking us through some of the technical opportunities, challenges & solutions the it has to offer.

Want to know more about unstructured data ? Join us on March 12th at 7:00 PM.

We will need first and last name plus an email address and a company name for security to issue visitor badges. These questions are part of the RSVP, please fill them out before hand to make registration smooth the night of the event.

-- Thanks

description:
In large organizations, it can take several weeks for a DBMS instance to be provisioned for a new development project, which limits innovation and agility. Mobile application developers need to concentrate more on development, and less on managing database infrastructure or growth. NoSQL Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) eliminates complexity, and enables instant provisioning of your data layer, so that you can begin new development quickly.

Now, developers can leverage the availability, elasticity, and reach of the cloud to create a data delivery network that enables applications to scale larger and remain available to users wherever they are.

Please join us on Thursday, March 19, 2015 as we discuss different NoSQL database genres, and how DBaaS will enable you to focus on app development, knowing that NoSQL in the cloud can scale to meet surging data needs. We will also cover JSON, the open standard format for data transmission, and how it integrates with a NoSQL cloud environment.

Space is limited, so sign up today.

ONLINE REGISTRATION IS NOW CLOSED. IF YOU WOULD LIKE TO ATTEND, PLEASE COME AND COMPLETE AN ON-SITE REGISTRATION FORM.

Join us for a very interesting Developer Day on Tuesday, March 24th at 8:30am in Troy, MI, hosted by Perficient (a premier IBM Business Partner) and the IBM Big Data & Analytics team.

In order to confirm your seat at this event (space is limited), you must register at this URL: http://ibm.co/1CUYPqU

The Internet of Things (IoT) is hot, but many are tired of the chatter and ready for action. Today’s applications are expected to manage a variety of structured and unstructured data, accessed by massive networks of users, devices, and business locations, or even sensors, vehicles and Internet-enabled goods.

In today’s continuously changing, always connected business environment, you must make the best possible decisions and put them into action immediately. Real-time actionable insight provides the robust big data and analytics capabilities that allow you to capture, analyze and act on all relevant data, including the stream of data generated by the myriad devices that make up the Internet of Things. Marketers, sales managers, financial analysts and other business users gain the insights they need to act in real time based on timely, trusted data.

As you expand big data and analytics capabilities throughout your organization, you need to empower all of your business users to access and analyze data for faster insight. Taking delivery of software, solutions, infrastructure, platforms and services on the cloud can accelerate the value of big data and analytics capabilities, offering scalability with limited upfront investment.

Join us to learn about how IBM and Perficient are helping clients rapidly deliver solutions to Capture, Analyze and Act on IoT data in Real-Time. The Developer Day kicks off at 8:30am with food and beverages/registration. Bring your laptop because after the morning session, our subject matter experts will help you get hands-on with the technology.

Agenda

6:30pm - 7pm: Pre-meeting conversation, networking, light refreshments 7pm - 8:30pm: Presentation, Q&A

Abstract

With humorous anecdotes from the pre-history of both projects, Andrew Clay Shafer will talk about today and tomorrow’s best practices for full-stack private cloud.

We'll talk hopes, dreams, and lessons learned. We'll talk about dev and we'll talk about ops, and what it all means in a cloud platform world. We'll start from the bottom of the stack and work up to the top. We'll go from history, to the state of the art with an eye on the future. You will laugh, you will cry, you will learn about stateful services in a 12 factor world. From bare metal to Linux Containers, and beyond... bring you thinking cap and a fresh change of clothes expecting a lively presentation followed by an even livelier discussion.

Speaker

Andrew Clay Shafer is a Senior Director of Technology working in, on and around Cloud Foundry at Pivotal. Andrew was involved in many system automation projects since his time as co-founder of Puppet Labs and lead some of the earliest and largest deployments of OpenStack as the VP of Engineering at Cloudscaling. He knows where most the bodies are buried, but genuinely wants people to have nice things.

description:
- Français:

Nous sommes ravis d'annoncer le lancement de la communauté "Big Data Developer" à Montréal. Nous espérons vous rencontrer tous pour notre évènement inaugural à Montréal. Ce groupe s'addresse aux développeurs, statisticiens et à tous les enthousiastes et les praticiens du Big Data. Nos meetups offrent une opportunité d`apprendre les dernières nouveautés dans le domaine des technologies Big Data et, pour certaines sessions d`avoir une expérience pratique sur les solutions Big Data et les outils associés. Pour la premier évènement qui va démarrer cette communauté, la session va être consacrée aux concepts clés de Hadoop (HDFS, MapReduce, YARN, Spark...), ainsi qu'une revue rapide du riche écosystème des projets Apache Open Source autour de Hadoop (HBase, Hive, Pig, Sqoop, Flume...). Cette session d`introduction sera suivie d'une session plus courte consacrée à l`exploitation du langage R sur Hadoop avec BigR, un composant de la distribution Hadoop d'IBM BigInsights. Cette première session sur Hadoop est très accessible s'addresse principalement à une audience familière avec la problématique de l'analyse de données en entreprise,d'intelligence d'affaires et des sciences de données et qui souhaite raffermir leurs connaissances de base sur Hadoop au délà des "buzz words", et sera particulièrement bénéfique à ceux qui font leur premier saut sur Hadoop.

- English:

We are thrilled to announce the launch of the Big Data Developer Meetup community in Montreal! We hope to see everyone out to the inaugural event in Montreal.This group is geared towards developers, data scientists and ALL Big Data enthusiasts and practitioners. Our meetups provide an opportunity to learn about the latest in Big Data technologies and get hands on experience on Big Data solution and tools. This being the first session to kick of the community, this session will focus to key concepts of Hadoop (HDFS, MapReduce, YARN, Spark...), as well as a quick overview of the rich ecosystem of Hadoop Apache Open Source projects around Hadoop (HBase, Hive, Pig, Sqoop, Flume...). This introductory session will be followed by a shorter session on using the langage R on Hadoop with BigR, a component of IBM Hadoop distribution BigInsights.

This first session on Hadoop is very accessible and is targeted primarily to an audience familiar with the problematic of enterprise analytics, business intelligence, and data science, who want to enrich their Hadoop knowledge beyond buzz words. The session will be particularly beneficial to those doing their first dive into Hadoop.
name: Big Data Developers Montreal Kick-off

description:
Tesla, BMW i8, they are very modern & fashion to cars, not only a new car, also a revolution for automotive industry.

But, there is a big gap to such electronic cars, "power provider".

Let's image, if those electronic cars can't get power as easy as fuel now for traditional cars, the revolution couldn't go further.

It will must be happened in the near future. We can be sure that millions of "power provider" lied on the roads, which "power provider" will provide easy, fast service to cars. There are many business opportunities to us. How to manage such a lot of "power provider"? What kind of value-added service we can find out?

We could meet-up and find the appropriate services which can host in cloud service.

e.g. Create a manage system for "power provider", and can listen every "power provider" node status, to schedule a maintenance plan.

It's brand new business for every company, and it's a "blue sea".

Let's discover the chance and take advantage.

description:
Dave Nielsen will come again to show you how to get started with the Cloud Foundry PaaS and deploy your first app on Cloud Foundry.

Workshop overview:

Part 1: an overview of the popular programming languages, and services that are currently available within Cloud Foundry.

Part 2: a step-by-step walk-through of how to develop a data-driven web application for Cloud Foundry and deploy it into Pivotal Web Services.

Remember to bring your own laptops!

About presenter:

Dave Nielsen, Cloud Computing Evangelist & Consultant

By day, Dave is a consultant helping firms engage with influential leaders in the developer & DevOps communities. He is particularly fascinated by Cloud Computing APIs and Platforms. By night, is the founder of CloudCamp, a community of 50,000 disruptive cloud enthusiasts and community organizers in 100+ cities around the world. Follow Dave on Twitter @davenielsen.
name: Hands-on Workshop: Deploy Your First App on Cloud Foundry

description:
Our first meetup will quickly introduce and demo IBM's PaaS, Bluemix.

You, a developer or a software entreprenuer now have a hand in creating the future and fast! Bluemix, an open-standard, cloud-based Public PaaS for building, hosting, managing, and running applications of all types, offers you all the instant services (APIs) , runtimes and infrastructure you need to push your ideas into the present.

This meetup will focus on rapid meaningful live demos. You will learn how to build and deploy killer web, mobile, IoT, big data, analytics and cognitive apps safe from technology lock-in.

Check it out for yourself now at www.bluemix.net

description:
Forget Kick-starting your startup. It’s all about Zooming Ahead!Throw out those Servers, Bring in the Cloud!- Marc Jones, Chief Technology Officer, SoftLayer

One of the biggest challenges for startups, no matter how brilliant the idea or, how innovative the app, is dealing with the technical side of business. Not only are you expected to get that out-of-the-box idea, plan for it, seek investors for it but you also have to seek the right technical infrastructure to take it to the masses. Well, who says you have to be technical to get that business off the ground. With everything on the cloud all you need to know about IT systems is click, point, order - and hey presto, your systems are up and running in minutes and hours, not days and months!

It’s a Cloud fest - Spend time with Marc Jones as he takes us through what are the latest products in the market and what other startups are doing with the technology.

Agenda:

1400 to 1415: Pre-networking1415 to 1430: Talk by Marc Jones1430 to 1600: Discussion + Q&A + Networking (Casual)

Registration: Plugin @ NUS Enterprise

Marc JonesChief Technology Officer, SoftLayer, an IBM Company

Marc Jones leads SoftLayer’s technology design and architecture teams, which focus on the development of new products and services and research and development in SoftLayer Labs. Prior to joining SoftLayer, Jones served as director of software product development for Rackspace’s cloud division.
name: An Afternoon with Marc Jones, CTO, SoftLayer

description:
Registration: EventBrite

Spend time with SoftLayer mentors and equip your startup's tech teams with the knowledge and technical know-how to scale your technical needs with efficiency and stability.

This module will be led by Phil Jackson. Phil is SoftLayer's Lead Developer Evangelist and is based in Dallas, Texas.

Managing Deployments Using the SoftLayer API, Docker and Salt

Use the SoftLayer API to provision servers, configure SSH keys, and manage nodes in a Docker managed application environment. Learn about Salt configuration management, Docker applications, and the SoftLayer command line utility. Then, build a blog server using these tools.

Phil JacksonLead Developer Advocate

As Softlayer’s lead developer advocate, Phil Jackson helps customers and partners integrate with the company’s API. He also architects SoftLayer’s Drupal websites, writes API documentation, and maintains the developer blog.
name: SoftLayer Developer Workshop
